journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Peculiar features of electrical resistivity and phase structure in 3-D porous nitinol after selective laser sintering/melting process

article-meta.aff: 1Ecole Nationale d’Ingénieurs de Saint-Etienne, DIPI Laboratory, France
2P.N. Lebedev Physics Institute, Russian Academy of Sciences, Russia

author-notes.corresp: I Shishkovsky, P.N. Lebedev Physics Institute, Samara branch, Russian Academy of Sciences, 443011 Samara, Russia. Email: shiv@fian.smr.ru

abstract.p: The main goal of this study is the peculiarities of shape memory effect in a porous nickel–titanium (NiTi intermetallic phase referred to as nitinol) fabricated via the selective laser sintering/melting process. The phase and structural transformation behaviour of the intermetallide is characterized by means of the scanning electron microscopy, energy dispersive X-ray and X-ray analysis. The effect of the laser sintering parameters and additional heating on the phase content and the thermal dependence of the electrical resistivity are discussed. Peaks and bulbs of the electrical resistivity are found to correspond to the start and finish temperatures of the austenite-to-martensite and reverse phase transitions, and this discovery can be useful for the shape memory effect estimation and optimization. Advantages and shortcomings in the application of this porous material as biological microelectromechanical systems are briefly considered.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Different approaches have been reported for studying of phase and structural transformations inside the nitinol (NiTi –intermetallic phase) shape memory alloys (SMAs) that proved to be potentially suitable for bio-medical applications, for example, as compatible implants and/or in biological microelectromechanical systems (bio-MEMS) (clamps, stents, forceps, etc.).1,2 Another important application is for drug delivery systems (DDSs) that are porous temperature-sensitive SMA filters with the beneficial ability to vary the channel diameter along the drug flow path in the living tissue.2,3 It was shown in the study described in Arutyunov et al.4 that the sintered three-dimensional (3-D) nitinol samples achieved the porosity value of 40%, low density ∼3.3–4.1 g/cm3 and high passivation susceptibility in acid and alkaline media suitable for the DDS applications. The phase and structural transformations were investigated through estimation of the stress–strain behaviour, mechanical loading response, and ultrasonic and thermal properties, with the aid of the X-ray diffraction (XRD) and electrical resistivity (ER).1,3,5–14 Earlier,2 we used the stress–strain method for the 3-D porous nitinol parts synthesized by the selective laser sintering (SLS) method aimed to ensure the shape memory effect (SME) and identification of the area of plasticity. It is known that the above-cited approaches have a common character for great volumes of SMA, while the XRD and ER provide more detailed information on the transformation occurring on the grain and crystalline levels. The ER method permits to study the phase transformations in metallic systems to define the composition of different metallic mixtures and conduct quantitative analysis of phases in a solid solution. During the cooling of nitinol, a high-temperature austenite phase transforms into a low-temperature martensite (monoclinic) phase and the transformation is accompanied by the intermediate (rhombohedral – R) phase generation. Hence, the ER method is a more effective way for determining the intermediate NiTi phase when compared to the measurements of ultrasonic and thermal properties. This method reveals the intrinsic behaviour of the SME. The R-phase appearance is signalled by an increase in ER. Upon a successive transformation from the intermediate phase to the low-temperature one, the ER decreases drastically and shows a peak associated with the start temperature of the transformation to the low-temperature phase.3,5–7 On the other hand, the NiTi SMA behaviour (the start and finish temperatures of the austenite/martensite transformation) is strongly sensitive to additional factors, for example, alloy content, preheating and/or strain cycling.1,8–14 The comparison of the X-ray analysis to ER measurements may help to understand the complicated nature of the phase and structural relationships in NiTi SMA.

The selective laser sintering/melting (SLS/SLM) technology has a great potential for fabrication of both porous and solid functional medical implants out of nitinol with a predefined and reproducible external and internal surface morphology. This article offers discussions of physical and mechanical properties of the porous NiTi synthesized by SLS/SLM and of the SME existence in this material. Peculiarities of the phase and structural transformation behaviour of the material are also analysed. In an earlier study, Shishkovsky15 the method for the specific ER measurement was proposed to register some SLS structure properties. In this study, this method is applied simultaneously with the X-ray analysis of porous samples synthesized by the SLS and SLM in order to compare the results concerning the SME existence.

sec.title: Materials and experimental procedure
sec.p: All the reagents used in experiments were purchased in French and Russian markets for chemical products and used as supplied.

The specification of powders used in the experiments at the DIPI laboratory, ENISE, France, is as follows: NiTi (–45 µm), pre-alloyed gas-atomized powder from TLS Technik GmbH & Co. Chemical composition (% wt) Ni – balance and Ti – 45%. Granulometric (i.e. grain size) parameters: equivalent diameter (weight by volume) d10 = 11.4, d50 = 25.5 and d90 = 37.5 µm.

The specification of powders used in the experiments at the Samara Branch of the Lebedev Physics Institute, Russian Academy of Sciences (LPI RAS) is as follows: nitinol graded PN55T45 from Polema Co., Tula, RF; nitinol contained 55% of Ni and 45% of Ti in the intermetallic phase of NiTi. PN55T45 particle size was ∼100 µm, which is comparable to the laser beam diameter and hatch distance.

Our experimental set-up at the Samara Branch of the LPI RAS for the SLS of powder composites (Figure 1) involved: (a) a continuous wave YAG: Nd+3 laser, λ = 1.06 µm; (b) deflectors for scanning the laser beam in the X–Y plane; (c) personal computer; (d) interchangeable lenses with f ∼149 and 336 mm (to obtain focused spots with D ∼50 and 100 µm, respectively); (e) mechanism for deposition and levelling of the powder mixture; and (f) vertically moving cylindrical platform. The laser beam scanned an area of 50 × 50 or 100 × 100 mm2 and was controlled by the PC through mechanical deflectors. The SLS set-up and optimal processing parameters for 2-D nitinol sample fabrication were described earlier.2,15 The laser power P ranged from 17 to 25.6 W and scan velocity v within the interval of 2.5–4.1 cm/s. Figure 1.
SLS set-up. 3-D: three dimensional and CAD: computer-aided design.

The PM 100 machine (Phenix Systems, ENISE, France, Yb – fibre laser, λ = 1.07 µm) has an equipment design typical for SLM.16 The laser parameters were power ∼50 W and beam diameter D = 70 µm. The one- and two-zone SLM were realized with the hatch distance Sh ∼80 µm and scan velocities v = 120, 140 and 160 mm/s. In order to systemize these different laser parameters in terms of energy input, the Andrew number was used, A = P × D/(v × D × Sh),2 describing the energy absorbed per surface unit (J/mm2). Flat monolayers were synthesized by a laser beam in the argon environment (10 × 30 × d mm, where d is the depth of monolayer, see Figure 2). Laser welding and low-resistivity solders were used to minimize the measurement errors. Figure 2.
View of a 2-D monolayer with laser-welded conductors and set-up for measurement of specific ER. 2-D: two dimensional; ER: electrical resistivity; USB: universal serial bus; DAC: digital-to-analogue converter; and ADC: analogue-to-digital converter.

The microstructure and element analysis of the phase and structural compositions of the synthesized samples was done by means of a scanning electronic microscope (SEM) LEO 1450 (Carl Zeiss) equipped with the energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) microanalysis INCA ENERGY 300, Oxford Instruments. The qualitative XRD was carried out by means of the DRON-3 diffractometer using the
Cu Kα
radiation.

The ER ρ was accurately measured by a four-probe potentiometric method (Figure 2) in the temperature range from −150 up to +200 °C. The used temperature range of the thermal cycling was much wider than that of the NiTi transformation. The reason for this is that the temperature points in porous heterogeneous structures governed by some rules could be displaced. An external heater and liquid nitrogen were employed to vary the temperature of the nitinol samples. The temperature was measured with a chromel–alumel thermocouple.

The relative accuracy of the resistivity measurement was checked by the accuracy of the temperature measurement (a relative accuracy of 0.1 °C) and was estimated to be within 10−4. The experimental data were digitized by the Labview program on digital-to-analogue converter/analogue-to-digital converter (LCard Co., Moscow, RF). The experimental set-up (Figure 2) was tested by measuring the cast NiTi alloy wire (Figure 4). The ER,
ρ
corresponded to the reference data for NiTi alloy wire with different diameters by the tabular value.1,15 Figure 4.
Dependency of specific ER, ρ (μΩ × mm), on temperature, Т (°C), in cast NiTi wire: diameter 1.8 – • and 0.5 – ▪ (mm). Solid (red) signs correspond to the heating stage and open (blue) to the cooling one. ER: electrical resistivity.

sec.title: Results
sec.p:
High-resolution SEM results of a nitinol surface by SLS and SLM are presented in Figure 3. In order to compare the resulting microstructures, SLS and SLM parameters that were approximately corresponding to each other with regard to the laser energy per unit surface (Andrew number) were selected. The morphology of SLS and SLM surfaces differed insignificantly under lower magnifications (Figure 3(a) and (d)), while on the micron level, the differences became marked. Substructures after the SLM were needle shaped (Figure 3(c)) and their sizes were ∼120–150 nm. After the SLS, they looked like a honeycomb (Figure 3(f)) with wall thicknesses of ∼100–140 nm. Similar regular honeycomb-type structures were earlier obtained by the nitinol synthesis with the controllable laser energy out of a mixture of Ni and Ti powders with an equiatomic content of components.17 The EDX analysis showed the correspondence of the surface element composition to the initial powders except for traces of nitrogen and oxygen which could be introduced during the powder preparation before the laser processing. Figure 3.
Surface microstructure of nitinol samples: (a, b and c) SLM, P = 50 W, v = 10 cm/s, D = 70 µm and Sh = 100 µm, magnification (a) ×200, (b) ×1500 and (c) ×12,000; (d, e and f) and SLS, P = 13.9 W, v = 5.7 cm/s and D = Sh = 100 µm, magnification (d) ×300, (e) ×1000 and (f) ×10000. SLM: selective laser melting and SLS: selective laser sintering.

The ER results of experimental set-up testing obtained by measuring the cast NiTi alloy wire are presented in Figure 4. Our measurements, in particular those for the wire of 0.5 mm diameter, agree with the data from paper,8 where the ER values for the austenite and martensite phases were determined,
ρA
= 8.371 × 10−4 Ω mm and
ρM
= 9.603 × 10−4 Ω mm. The curves of ER of porous samples versus temperature for the cooling and heating within the temperature range from −150 to +200 °C are shown in Figures 5(a), 6(a) and 7(а). In these figures, each of the two curves consists of two parts. The stage of the porous NiTi sample heating from −150 up to +200 °C is given in a solid (red) colour and the cooling stage from +200 down to −150 °C in a open (blue) colour. Numbers (1–3) denote the corresponding laser parameters (specific energy input) used to produce these samples. Figure 5.
(a) ER of porous NiTi synthesized by SLS versus temperature and (b) diffraction patterns of the corresponding samples. Laser parameters are: A = 4.15 (1), 5.24 (2) and 6.24 J/mm2 (3), v = 4.1 cm/s and D = Sh = 100 µm. The black curve in Figure 5(b) corresponds to the initial PN55T45 powder without any laser treatment. ER: electrical resistivity and SLS: selective laser sintering.
Figure 6.
(a) ER of porous NiTi synthesized by SLM versus temperature and (b) diffraction patterns of the corresponding samples, one-zone laser scanning. Laser parameters are: A = 3.91 (1), 4.46 (2) and 5.21 J/mm2 (3), P = 50 W, D = 70 µm and Sh = 80 µm. The black curve in Figure 6(b) (as well as the curve in Figure 7(b)) corresponds to the initial TLS powder with no laser treatment. ER: electrical resistivity and SLM: selective laser melting.
Figure 7.
(a) ER of porous NiTi synthesized by SLM versus temperature and (b) diffraction patterns of the corresponding samples, two-zone laser scanning. Laser parameters are: A = 3.91 (1), 4.46 (2) and 5.21 J/mm2 (3), P = 50 W, D = 70 µm and Sh = 80 µm. ER: electrical resistivity and SLM: selective laser melting.

The results of the XRD analysis of the same samples are shown in Figures 5(b), 6(b) and 7(b). The ‘in’ index corresponds to the initial NiTi powder before the laser treatment. The patterns of a specific resistivity versus temperature and XRD for the samples sintered by the SLS are given in Figure 5; similar data for the SLM samples are presented in Figures 6 and 7. The samples described in Figure 7 were processed twice: first the laser beam scanned the surface along the sample short side (10 mm, see Figure 2), then along its long side (30 mm).

This repeated laser scanning is aimed to ensure the thermal re-cycling of the nitinol surface. It is known from other studies5–7,12,13 that the multi-cycling influences the history of the phase and structural transformations in a way similar to the SME effect.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: As mentioned in the ‘Introduction’ section, during heating, a peak must appear in the specific ER curve within the range of the austenite transformation. Under cooling, a similar peak corresponds to the martensite transformation from a high-temperature phase for the NiTi to a low-temperature one. It can be expected that the SME develops in the NiTi sample. Besides, for almost equiatomic TiNi alloys, the martensitic transformation (B2 → R → B19) can occur through the intermediate R-phase, depending on the thermo-mechanical treatment.3,5–7,18 At the beginning, the martensitic transformation yields a larger deformation of the lattice than the R-phase transition and is significantly affected by the internal stress field. A strong stress field resulting from rapid cooling will hinder the formation of martensite. Since the R-phase transformation is not so greatly affected by the internal stress field due to a low deformation of the lattice form, this promotes the formation of the R-phase in the inter-dendritic zones where a lower cooling rate is observed. The dislocations’ accumulation, depending on their density and interaction, provokes either the nucleation site formation for the martensitic phase or the slow down of martensitic plate motion. The pinning down of the martensitic plate motion paves the way to the R-phase formation.5 A significant overlap of the diffraction peaks of 1 1 0B2 and the R-phase complicates a clear detection of these phases.12

It is known that the porosity of nitinol leads to the austenite–martensite peak leap relative to the temperature axis, and the transformation temperature range expands while shifting towards the low-temperature zone as well. For example, it was shown in Botterill and Grant8 that a deflection from the NiTi phase stoichiometry by 2% only displaces the peak of martensite transformation by 10°. The martensite transformation peak shifts during strain hardening, adding of alloying elements in cast NiTi and/or under porosity changing.1 Papers3,8,10,12–14 showed a similar dependence on the temperature for differential scanning calorimetry peaks caused by the phase transformations. One can observe from Figures 5(a), 6(a) and 7(a) that the intervals of the austenite and martensite transformations are significantly displaced and broadened in case of a synthesized NiTi use, in contrast to a cast NiTi application. For porous NiTi, the specific ER is one order higher than the tabular ρ-values for the cast material.13 Moreover, papers1,15 testify to the possibility of the other intermetallic phases presence in the laser-synthesized NiTi.

Studies1,9,15 showed that the variation of the Ni content by 0.1 at.% results in changing the transformation temperature by approximately 10 °C; the presence of 1.0 at.% oxygen decreases the martensite transformation temperature by 92.6 K and makes the parental phase brittle. Additional stable phases (NiTi2, Ni3Ti) do not exhibit any shape memory behaviour but their formation modifies the composition of the remaining NiTi matrix and, hence, the transformation temperature. The comparison carried out in this study showed that in the synthesized NiTi samples, the intervals of the phase and structural transformations shift towards the negative temperature area due to the combination of the above-mentioned reasons in a lesser degree. The laser treatment of nitinol was carried out in protective atmosphere of argon, and X-ray analysis did not show these phases. So, we explain the great shift by the influence of porosity factor that achieved the level of 45% in case of SLS.1,17

An earlier study15 showed an upper limit in the resistivity curve during cooling caused by the presence of R-phase in a nitinol sample synthesized by the combination of SLS and self-propagated high-temperature synthesis reaction in the Ni + Ti equiatomic mixture. In Figure 5(a), 1–3 show the ER curves of SLS samples obtained at different laser energy inputs. With an increase of absorbed laser energy, the ER drops by the absolute value, and the R-peaks are hardly noticeable on the ER curves (2 and 3). In spite of this, the XRD pattern shows a weak presence of R-phase (1–10). The residual austenite is contained in the solid solution after laser sintering. During the SLM (Figure 6(a)), the R-phase peak is feeble, though with an increase in the laser energy input, it is enhanced. The X-ray analysis correlated with these results partially. Besides, the SLM is characterized by a great amount of the martensite phase and clear R-phase peaks (Figure 6(b)). Finally (Figure 7(b)), an additional two-zone laser scanning leads to the decrease of R-phase in the XRD pattern and to the increase of both martensite and austenite phases. It is seen from Figure 7(a) (curve 1) that no peak in ER is observed during heating since with the temperature rise the low-temperature phase is transformed directly into the higher one. The ER drop (Figure 7(a), curve 1) at the cooling stage is not so rapid, if we compare this curve slope with the slopes of curves 2 or 3 at the cooling stage. Meanwhile, upon evaluating the dynamics of the curve slope (Figures 5(a), 6(a) and (7a)) change under transition from SLS to SLM processes and further transition to two-zone SLM, it could be concluded that the change of the curve slope for the ER dependence in the minus-temperature region is substantial, and it is maximum for the two-zone SLM process (Figure 7(a)). Actually, the peak absence at the heating stage (Figure 7(a), curve 1) deserves special attention and may be an object for a further separate study. In both cases (Figures 6(a) and 7(a)), the ER increases with the laser input increase in contrast to the SLS (Figure 5(a)). A further research is needed to find out the reasons for this ER behaviour depending on the absorbed laser energy and in particular for additional laser thermocycling. An increase in the ER under the transformation was registered within the temperature range of a low-temperature phase for the SLS samples; this can only be attributed to the defects that occurred during the transformation as affirmed in Matsumoto.7 A detailed comparison of the hysteresis loop for the SLS and SLM samples is provided.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
The evolution of the specific ER as a function of the laser-processing parameters was experimentally studied for the first time in porous nitinol samples synthesized by the SLS/SLM methods. To verify the dependencies established, the samples were subjected to the X-ray analysis. The main experimental results can be summarized as follows:
The absolute value of the ER of the porous NiTi samples is one order higher than that of the solid NiTi wire.
The ER measurement was proved to be a good method for the identification of various phases and the SME in the porous nitinol SMA.
The ER of the phases studied (austenite, R-phase, martensite) increases with the temperature rise but the slopes of this increase are quite different.
The R-phase generally shows a higher ER than the austenite phase, but its value grows with the temperature decrease for SLS samples. This is explained by the accumulation of dislocations with a continuous increase of the R-phase with the temperature decrease. No similar dependence is observed for the SLM samples.
The hysteresis loop of the ER is more remarkable in the SLS than in SLM porous samples.
The evaluation showed that under transition from SLS to SLM processes and further transition to two-zone SLM, the curve slope for the ER dependence in the minus-temperature region changes substantially and achieves its maximum for the two-zone SLM process.
The ER method proposed by the authors makes it possible to estimate the temperature interval where the SME may be expected. The cooling curves of the porous NiTi showed that the SME can shift within the low-temperature region owing to reasons connected with porosity.

The ER can be used as a feedback generator for the direct control of the actuator location with no need for any other sensors. Owing to the SME in the porous nitinol, synthesized layer-by-layer by the SLS/SLM, and to the possibility of manufacturing 3-D objects such as bio-MEMS sensors, DDSs, implants, etc., a new quality level can be achieved in the orthopaedic surgery through the development of self-initiating, self-fixing and self-swinging prosthetic elements at a human body temperature.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: The study was supported by the grants of the Russian Academy of Sciences (RAS) Presidium in the frame of the programme ‘Fundamental Sciences for Medicine – 2010-2011’ and Russian Foundation of Basis Researches (RFBR), project no. 10-08-00208-a.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The authors are deeply grateful to Prof. Y G Morozov (ISMAN, Chernogolovka) for the SEM analysis fulfilled by him.
